thread.title: American Airlines Lands on L.A. Times Front Page
thread.title_full: American Airlines Lands on L.A. Times Front Page - WSJ

author: Steven Perlberg
title: American Airlines Lands on L.A. Times Front Page
text:
1 COMMENTS American Airlines on Monday placed an enormous advertisement on the front page of the Los Angeles Times, another example of how print media companies have given up more real estate to marketers in recent years.
The ad, which hawks American Airlines’ service from the Los Angeles airport LAX, begins under the masthead and wraps around the left side of the page, jutting through to the bottom where it instructs readers to look at more ads on pages A8 and A9.
The L.A. Times has run large ad units on its front page before. Most recently, “minion” characters graced the top of the page over the actual words “Los Angeles Times” to promote their eponymous film.
The ad placement comes during a turbulent period for the paper and its owner Tribune Publishing. On Monday, CEO Jack Griffin sent a memo to employees outlining a buyout program. Last month, the company fired L.A. Times Publisher Austin Beutner just a year after he was hired.
Some observers on social media said the all-encompassing ad marked a sign of the tough times. One Twitter TWTR 6.99 % user even noticed that a “San Francisco” dateline for a story—which the ad sticks into— was misspelled .
Large ads on the front pages of print products have become more commonplace in recent years, including at The Wall Street Journal, as ad dollars shifted from print to digital. Last year, Verizon ran ads on the covers of Time Inc. titles Time and Sports Illustrated, bucking a sacrosanct convention about leaving ads off of magazine covers.
An American Airlines spokesperson said the front page ad is part of a larger fall advertising campaign focusing on Los Angeles, Chicago and New York. The campaign also includes digital and out-of-home advertising but “print is still a huge thing for us,” the spokesperson said.
According to Kantar Media, American Airlines spent $3.9 million on newspaper ads last year, down from about $5.5 million the year prior.
